author: daniellehrner
content:
I have a doubt about the Hive test `ForkchoiceUpdated Invalid Payload Attributes`. I think it is not correct.

The part of the spec that is tested states:
> Client software MUST ensure that payloadAttributes.timestamp is greater than timestamp of a block referenced by forkchoiceState.headBlockHash. If this condition isn't held client software MUST respond with -38003: Invalid payload attributes and MUST NOT begin a payload build process. In such an event, the forkchoiceState update MUST NOT be rolled back.

My doubt is about the last part:

> forkchoiceState update MUST NOT be rolled back.

So even though we return an error we have to apply the forkchoice update, meaning updating  headBlockHash and finalizedBlockHash, to the new values that were sent by the request. In the test it seems we don't have to apply this update and only should return the error.

author: daniellehrner
daniellehrner
content:
In Besu this fails because, we have applied the forkchoice update from the first call and have set finalizedBlockHash to `0xfdc2e9aa78716a8402e207c888bcf85a2b212b9055171c3216d17debcb7b006f`. But in the second call finalizedBlockHash is supposed to be `0xb54a47b2ee11a6e3e0d637b1ad11b5b067ec050c397bbe6420beea6733b08e0f` instead, which only can be successful if the forkchoice update  from the first call is rolled back.

Is my understanding correct that the test is incorrect? Or do we have to change the behavior in Besu?
